channel.title: NPR Programs: Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Sarah Mullally named first woman Archbishop of Canterbury
item.description: Sarah Mullally has been named as the new Archbishop of Canterbury. She's the first woman ever chosen to lead the world's 85 million Anglicans.
item.content:encoded: Sarah Mullally has been named as the new Archbishop of Canterbury. She's the first woman ever chosen to lead the world's 85 million Anglicans.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Frayer

item.title: Government shutdown enters third day as White House threatens widespread layoffs
item.description: As the government shutdown enters its third day, the GOP-led Senate will vote for the fourth time on partisan stopgap bills. Meanwhile, the White House is threatening mass layoffs for federal workers.
item.content:encoded: As the government shutdown enters its third day, the GOP-led Senate will vote for the fourth time on partisan stopgap bills. Meanwhile, the White House is threatening mass layoffs for federal workers.
item.dc:creator: Claudia Grisales

item.title: Karoline Leavitt says White House must cut spending due to shutdown
item.description: White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt says the Trump administration has to look at ways to "save money in a responsible way that respects the American taxpayer's money" during shutdown.
item.content:encoded:
White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt says the Trump administration has to look at ways to "save money in a responsible way that respects the American taxpayer's money" during shutdown.

(Image credit: Evan Vucci)
item.dc:creator: Obed Manuel

item.title: Shutdown standoff not about whether Democrats or GOP 'win or lose,' says Sen. Warnock
item.description: Georgia Sen. Raphael Warnock, a Democrat, says health care spending cuts hurt people regardless of party affiliation and that he is "hoping against hope" that the GOP and White House will negotiate.
item.content:encoded:
Georgia Sen. Raphael Warnock, a Democrat, says health care spending cuts hurt people regardless of party affiliation and that he is "hoping against hope" that the GOP and White House will negotiate.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: Obed Manuel

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Government shutdown enters day three with no resolution in sight, the monthly jobs report is delayed because of the shutdown, and the White House pressures universities to adopt Trump-aligned compact.
item.content:encoded: Government shutdown enters day three with no resolution in sight, the monthly jobs report is delayed because of the shutdown, and the White House pressures universities to adopt Trump-aligned compact.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: 'We the People' explores the history and complexities of the U.S. Constitution
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with U.S. historian Jill Lepore about her new book, "We the People: A History of the U.S. Constitution."
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with U.S. historian Jill Lepore about her new book, "We the People: A History of the U.S. Constitution."
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: White House urges colleges to sign compact aligned with Trump's agenda
item.description: The White House is pressuring colleges to align with President Trump's agenda, urging multiple schools across the country to sign a "compact" in exchange for priority access to federal grants.
item.content:encoded: The White House is pressuring colleges to align with President Trump's agenda, urging multiple schools across the country to sign a "compact" in exchange for priority access to federal grants.
item.dc:creator: Elissa Nadworny

item.title: Central banks globally have faced political pressure. Here's what happened there
item.description: President Trump is continuing his push for more control of the Federal Reserve. The Planet Money team looked into what has happened globally when central banks face political pressure.
item.content:encoded: President Trump is continuing his push for more control of the Federal Reserve. The Planet Money team looked into what has happened globally when central banks face political pressure.
item.dc:creator: Mary Childs

item.title: Michigan wants to limit how long drivers can stay at rest stops
item.description: Michigan transportation officials want to limit how long drivers can stop at rest areas to 48 hours. People who live in their vehicles say that would remove one of their few safe options.
item.content:encoded: Michigan transportation officials want to limit how long drivers can stop at rest areas to 48 hours. People who live in their vehicles say that would remove one of their few safe options.
item.dc:creator: Maxwell David Howard

item.title: Slurp with care: 'KPop Demon Hunters' instant noodle trend can cause burn injuries
item.description: Fans of "KPop Demon Hunters" are trying ramyun, the Korean instant noodles enjoyed by the film's heroes. But doctors say you should slurp with caution to avoid burns. Here's how to stay safe.
item.content:encoded: Fans of "KPop Demon Hunters" are trying ramyun, the Korean instant noodles enjoyed by the film's heroes. But doctors say you should slurp with caution to avoid burns. Here's how to stay safe.
item.dc:creator: Hosts
